direction.raw_text: well-groomed, khaki slacks, leather jacket, tippet-like scarf, belt pouch, "Beatle" boots, a shadow drifting in and out of other shadows, New York, day, night: watching, listening, rarely speaking -- nonexistent, seen only by those he sees. His face an affable blank. Make of it what you will. The eyes flicker; the hands shift discreetly. A map of calculation. Once he had a drug problem. Life turned a page. Today he follows instructions: he sleeps light -- one eye open, anticipating. JOHN LETOUR, D.D., loner, voyeur, has been drifting toward an unknown destination. At mid-life the destination draws near. The circle tightens. The dealer is anxious. The destination is love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : New York by night. JOHN LETOUR nestles in back of a blue car service sedan, face reflected in the window. Neon mixes with steam, street people with tourists, young dates: each with a different agenda, a hidden purpose. His beeper goes off. He clicks it, checks the digital message. The DRIVER stops at an uptown corner. LETOUR opens the curbside door, motions to the DRIVER he'll be back in "ten" minutes. He enters the video laundromat, a twenty-four-hour video rental/laundromat/tanning salon. Inside, he meets a RETRO-YUPPIE (J. Crew Division) in the "Classics" section. They exit. On the sidewalk, money is exchanged for a packet. LETOUR pockets the uncounted cash. The YUPPIE mouths goodbye, eager to put distance between him and LETOUR. JOHN checks his beeper, stops at a pay phone, dials.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: NIGHT IN THE LIFE CREDIT SEQUENCE

direction.raw_text: re-enters the sedan; the DRIVER heads downtown. High-rises give way to Tudor City. Uncollected trash lines the curbs. LETOUR eyes a PEDESTRIAN; PEDESTRIAN looks back. Later. Three a.m. The streets are dark. LeTour's car passes a glowing Korean market.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: narrates from diary:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sedan drives on. End credits.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (voice over) Labor Day weekend. Some time for a sanitation strike. Everybody crazy to stock up. They decide to score at the last minute and want it now. Never fails. The faces look alike. You gotta use memory tricks: each has some peculiarity -- it keeps you sharp. A D.D. told me when a drug dealer starts writing a diary it's time to quit. I started writing after that. Not every night -- now and then. Just to burn off the night. Fill up one book, throw it out, start another.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Four a.m.: streets empty. LeTour's sedan drops him off near a ten-story West 80s apartment building. JOHN gives the DRIVER a forty-dollar tip (standard procedure), turns the corner. He presses the intercom; a buzzer unlocks the door. He enters the lobby, walks past English reproduction furniture toward the elevators. Presses the button. Penthouse C door opens. ANN lets JOHN in with a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: forty-four, striking in a tailored dress, greets him with a wet kiss. Her hair is coiffured, her face made up. She is John's employer, mentor, confidante, Mother Hen: she keeps the books. Her ingenuous demeanor belies sterner stuff: she's been in the drug business fifteen years. Ann's apartment is a jumble of sensibilities: dark green walls, zebra-skin sofa, Haitian wall friezes, framed magazine photos of Paramahansa Yogananda, Liz Taylor, the Duke of Windsor -- paintings stacked behind an oversized urn. A bird flits in its cage. One corner of the living area is devoted to a fledgling cosmetics business: Macintosh computer, billboard of trade paper clippings and ads, herbal samples, reference books, color charts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: fifty, slight, waves hello as JOHN locks the door. Gay, hip, worn, he's John's "co-runner." They work -- and eat -- out of Ann's apartment. Take-out tins of Indian food are stacked amid crystals, tarot cards, glasses, and vitamin bottles. No sign of drugs, drug paraphernalia, or money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Repartee: the plumbing of family feeling.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Have we made New York safe for another weekend?

direction.raw_text: First light reflects across the Hudson as LETOUR walks west on 22nd Street toward his Chelsea apartment building. A delivery truck passes uncollected garbage. He enters a nondescript doorway. Inside his studio apartment, JOHN sits at a second-hand table writing in a composition book. He drinks from an eight-ounce glass of white wine, continues. The room has little personality; Ann's apartment has enough for two. Nails indicate where pictures once hung; a boombox sits on the linoleum floor amid cassettes, books (Autobiography of a Yogi, The Secret Doctrine), fashion magazines, a stack of unopened CDs. A futon is unrolled beneath the room's sole decoration, a poster of a human foot advertising a forgotten photo exhibit. Wine bottles -- Chenin Blanc. Precious little to show for forty years. LeTour's narration resumes as he writes:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (voice over) "Labor Day." "Union Movement" -- there's a contradiction in terms. I know about long hours. It's worse when I'm off -- I just walk and walk. Where am I going? There's an element of providence to it all. Like rolling numbers. Luck. You're walking down the street, some guy that looks maybe a little like you does a stick-up four hours ago, there's an APB description out and a cop pulls you in cause he's cold and wants to go inside -- they grab your stash. Your number's up. You're busted for nothing. For bad luck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Later. Narration continues as sedan drives through rain. Later. A Tribeca loft. LETOUR swaps drug jargon with TWO N.Y.U. STUDENTS at an impromptu party. Attractive ingenues drift by. TRENDY TWOSOME, blasted, sways, to techno-rap. Business done, LETOUR turns to leave. The FIRST STUDENT grabs his shoulder:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing) ...but -- if there's no God, how can man conceive of him? The idea of God presupposes the existence of God. That's the Ontological Argument. Anselm. Twelve hundred. Fourteen hundred -- I'm not sure -- LETOUR (checks his watch) I've got to go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gesturing) Let me finish. Okay, if the idea of God is implanted by God -- the sensus divinitatus, the sense of the divine -- what is the role of human thought? Not faith, thought...

dialogue.raw_text: (Voice over) Everybody wants to talk. It's like a compulsion. My philosophy is: you got nothing to say, don't say it. They figure you can tell a D.D. anything, things they would never tell anyone else. He understands. Of course they're stoned to start. If I could tie together all the hours of coke talk I've heard, that would be a lot of string. It was Robert's idea to add twenty-five dollars to home deliveries cause it's such a hassle. Fifty is more like it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's only four of us and like seven of them -- and we're paying for the dope. See her, over there, the blonde, long hair, yellow skirt? -- she's gonna model for Elite.

direction.raw_text: LeTour's sedan heads down Lexington Avenue. It rains unabated. Puddles glisten; red taillights refract on the windshield. JOHN rests in back, a bag from Enhancements beside him. Pedestrians, well-dressed and casual, desperately wave for taxis amid sacks of garbage. No use: nothing for blocks. John's sedan stops for a midtown light. LETOUR looks out the window, sees a WOMAN vainly hailing a cab. He looks again. She turns her head. He recognizes her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leans over, opens the far door, calls:

direction.raw_text: fortyish, professionally young, is compact, demure; she wears business jacket and skirt, patterned blouse. Nothing about her is remotely paranormal -- nothing except, of course, her "aura." The "Other Side." Her voice is at the same time soothing, piercing. Teresa's West Village consultation room is startlingly mundane: a bourgeois walk-up. Upholstered furniture, Tiffany objets d'art, framed photos of her husband and children -- a trip to Capri. A twenties portrait of Madame Blavatsky, above the fireplace, centers the room.
direction.name: direction

He joins the FRENCH COUPLE, declines a drink, exchanges drugs/money amid air kisses. Late night. Fog hangs over 22nd Street: Chelsea's deserted. Homeless men behind windbreaks of trash. John's apartment. He writes bareback at the desk. He completes his composition book diary mid-sentence, closes it, discards it. He lifts a new book from the floor, opens it on the desk, continues. He fills his glass with wine:

dialogue.raw_text: (voice over) I can always find another way to make a living. I never planned this in the first place -- not like Ann. She came up to sell, have parties, make contacts. She was so glamorous. I just wanted to be around her. She'd sit up listening to coke stories. Now it's me and Robert. The whole crowd was the same age. Everybody's younger now. She made me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: pulls his weekly pay from his pants, puts five twenties in an envelope. He addresses the envelope. "Linda Wichel, 1012B-2 A Street, Sacramento, California," stamps it. Dissolves: (1) LETOUR vanishes from his desk, (2) materializes fetally on his futon, bareback, slacks, boots, anxious, awaiting sleep. LeTour's diary contains parallel columns of names: one headed "People Who Are Left Handed," the other, "People Whose Eyes Don't Match."

direction.raw_text: Midday. JOHN, wearing a black tweed jacket, tie, khaki slacks, mails the Sacramento letter, enters COTE BASQUE, a hoity- toity 55th Street restaurant. Midmeal. ANN and LETOUR sit in a prominent booth; power moguls confer quietly. A deferential WAITER brings fresh berries, retrieves empty salmon plates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The CHEF stops by, asks if the meal was satisfactory. ANN assures him it was, kisses his hand. The CHEF nods, gratified. JOHN resumes the conversation:

dialogue.raw_text: There's some. Not much. A thousand or two. Maybe more -- I'm not sure.

dialogue.raw_text: Kitty Ford once told me, "Ann, the only person I know that lives as well as you is my grandmother." All the money I've made, all the money I've spent -- it never adds up. This last two years cosmetics' been taking everything.

(crosses fingers) His wife says he gets straight or she cuts him off. Old money. I remember the last thing he said to me: "See you soon." Yeah, sure. That was five years ago.

direction.raw_text: Afternoon. St. Luke's. LETOUR, wearing tweed jacket, walks down the corridor, checks room numbers. A NURSE passes. He stops at a room, pushes the door a crack, peeks inside, quietly enters. Inside the hospital room, MRS. JOST, sixty-five, lies sedated, attached to IV tubes and a respirator. Flowers wreathe the bed.

direction.raw_text: sleeps in a chair by the window.

direction.raw_text: looks from MRS. JOST to RANDI and back again: a vibrant woman reduced to a shell. He soundlessly eases into a vacant chair. His mind goes back.

direction.raw_text: twists fitfully in her chair. A stuffed bear peeks over family photos on the window sill.

direction.raw_text: steps into the doorway, stops, frozen -- watching the tableau: JOHN, RANDI, her mother. Her face is ravaged: the death watch has taken its toll. LETOUR reaches his arm, touches the hospital bed.

direction.raw_text: She puts her finger to her lips. He nods. She steps closer, holds him politely. His cheek nestles in her neck. They turn toward the door, step into the corridor, walk arm in arm as if supporting each other.

direction.raw_text: They kiss deeper, bodies grinding. The painful present fades. A NURSE approaches with WHEELCHAIR PATIENT. She tries to pass one side of JOHN and MARIANNE, tries the other side, is blocked again. The NURSE stops, stares at their soap opera. Sensing her glare, JOHN and MARIANNE, hands over and under each other, stop, look to the NURSE: embarrassed -- yet blissful.

dialogue.raw_text: (after a moment) I always thought my father would die first. He would die, then my mother and I would reconcile. Just her and me. I hated him for living.

dialogue.raw_text: What it felt like. (kisses his face) What this tasted like.

direction.raw_text: and MARIANNE are all over each other. The pain of the moment, the pain of the past are subsumed by passion. Blind, welcome sexuality. Naked, they kneel facing each other on the bed, faded bleeding heart tattoo on his bicep:

The ITALIAN turns; LETOUR glimpses his face: too pale. The ITALIAN averts his eyes. Glancing back, LETOUR walks up the stairs to Tis' table.

Port Authority hustlers -- male, female -- cruise as TRANSIT COPS whack an emaciated CRACKHEAD. JOHN, lit by neon, lowers his power window. John's apartment. Night. He writes in his diary, drinks.

direction.raw_text: She re-enters the funeral chapel.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry. That's the way it is. You shouldn't have come. Marianne has been up all night, crying and crying. She wasn't there when Mother passed -- died -- she blames herself. It wouldn't have made any difference. She just slipped away. Marianne's -- I'm worried --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, you. I can't think of anything, but if there was anything I could do...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks. I'm okay -- I guess. I mean, we've been expecting it. It'll hit me later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your mother. I came in the room. You were sleeping. I just watched.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. (beat) I'd better get back. Marianne's probably flipping out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Eight p.m. LETOUR, direct from Plaza Memorial, enters Ann's apartment. ANN, coiffured and made up, gestures to take-out tins:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Have some shu mai. Just delivered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (entering) I told Ann you'd be on time. Tis called. He said before ten. He said you were right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: An undercover cop. Not a narc. The Park murder. Jealous was straight on that -- you hear anything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Remember the time that cop called here? Wanted to know if we had "nose candy"? (laughs) Ann says, "John Candy?" "John Candy?"
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: looks at JOHN, approaches:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kitchen phone rings. A voice follows the pre-recorded message:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's wrong baby? You like like shit. Something wrong? (holds his face)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't fool me. I can read you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (distressed) What do you care? You're leaving me. A few more months -- sayonara. (to ROBERT) You too. John who? What was his name again? Le --? (to ANN: pained) I mean it's not exactly like I got a pension plan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (takes his hands) Johnny, it's not that at all. Is that what you think? You hate cosmetics. You don't care about it. You told me that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got a friend -- a D.D. -- got into lapidary. I'll introduce you. You have to pass a test.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Any more about the Park murder?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (genuine) You want in? We'll make a place for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (out of shot -- answering machine) "Ann, this is Ed. You gotta come. The other thing is over. I'll be home all night. 749-2876."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (unequivocal) Don't answer it. Let him call all night. He's trouble. I don't want to deal with him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's alright, I'll go. Let me handle it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry if -- ANN (about EDDIE) He gives you shit -- fuck him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're going Chinese tonight, okay? I mean we're on a roll -- ANN Spring roll.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (preparing to leave) Sure, whatever. Surprise me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Eddie's high-rise apartment. EDDIE is worse, if anything. He's been scoring on the street: broken pipes and vials crunch underfoot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and LETOUR argue ("Fuck you!" "Fuck you!"). EDDIE spits, pushes TOUR, JOHN pushes back. Eddie's feet tangle. He trips, FALLS. A bottle SMASHES.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: goes to the phone, checks Eddie's directory, dials.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (on floor) You gotta get permission? Check with Mama?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, the lawyer in Bronxville. I'm gonna ask him to come over. (EDDIE protests) You've told me so much about him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (panicked) No, don't. Please, I'll give you money, anything. He doesn't understand. Whose side are you on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on phone) Is this Martin Jeer? (beat) Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: woozy, tries to stand.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to EDDIE) I recommend Hazelden. It has the best all-around program. (on phone) Martin Jeer? (beat) I'm here with your brother Ed. (beat) Yeah, in the city. I'm afraid there's a medical emergency. You're going to have to come.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: lurches toward LETOUR. JOHN -- flash of anger -- bootkicks him in the head! Eddie's cheek hits the carpet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: cooling down, measures his breaths. A spring can only be wound so tight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: walks from his sedan around the corner to the Lexington Avenue entrance to Grace Towers, a pre-war apartment building. In the lobby, he gives his name to the SECURITY GUARD, is directed to the express elevator. He exits on the thirtieth floor; footsteps muted by thick carpet. Victorian prints on dark blue walls. He looks about, approaches a door, presses the buzzer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: opens the door; JOHN enters Tis' opulent apartment. Salle and Clemente hang on the walls; New York twinkles outside panoramic windows. A pipe and syringe lie atop art books. TIS, in jogging sweats, comes from the bedroom to greet him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Tour, just in time. We were out. Nineteen, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some, not the whole thing. (to THOMAS) You got hundreds?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: hands him a plastic bag of gram envelopes. TIS opens a packet, pours the contents on the coffee table.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I like that about Ann. Always takes the time to grind it. If you do it, do it right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: hears footsteps, turns to see MARIANNE stumble out of the bedroom! She looks terrible: shoeless, blouse out, hair undone, bruise on her forehead -- perhaps she fell against something -- hands trembling.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to MARIANNE) Looks like you could use some help. (MARIANNE looks up, sees JOHN, goes pale) Mari, this is Tour. You got any hundreds?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: stares speechless: the girl who won't talk to him because he's a dealer. MARIANNE bolts back into the bedroom, SLAMS the door!
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Not the talkative type. Haven't seen her in years. You know her, don't you? (no answer. TIS counts the money, offers it. LETOUR is frozen) Why they call me? What a nightmare. (extending money) You want it or not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: pockets the cash. TIS, his arm on John's elbow, "walks" him to the door:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: nudges JOHN to the corridor, closes the door behind him. JOHN looks toward the elevator; TIS, behind the door, calls "Marianne!" Time cut: LETOUR stands in the elevator, red floor numbers flashing past, blank eyes mirrored in dark glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: exits Grace Towers, walks past a limo toward Lexington Avenue. Rounding the corner, he sees his blue sedan. He looks at the cash, repockets it. He continues slowly, each step a separate task.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: reaches for the door handle. A scream pierces traffic noise. A car screeches, another. Voices call out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: steps back, listens. He retraces his steps, turns onto Lexington Avenue. The SECURITY GUARD, walkie-talkie in hand, clusters on the sidewalk with the limo driver, two pedestrians. A cabbie jumps from his taxi, joins the confusion ("My God!"). A siren approaches. John's beeper goes off. Drawing closer, LETOUR sees the partial bloodied shape of a broken body on the sidewalk: he recognizes Marianne's skirt. A squad car brakes with a screech. TWO COPS converge, climb over trash, clear the crime scene:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A second squad car pulls up. JOHN turns away, walks around the corner.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who saw it? What happened? (the FEMALE COP bends over Marianne's body)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: opens the car door, closes it, sits inside. A wailing ambulance flashes past, speeds up Central Park West.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: doesn't react. Beeper re-beeps; he disconnects the battery. The driver, CARLOS, twenty-five, Hispanic, shirt starched, turns, looks, thinks, says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause. More police cars. The EMS siren starts up; the ambulance speeds downtown past LeTour's sedan. No reaction. CARLOS turns off the engine.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where to, sir? Where are we going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a moment) You want me to wait here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: starts the car, pulls into traffic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John's apartment. Late night. LETOUR, barefoot, T-shirt, slacks, stands flat against the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: broadcasts twenty-four hour news on the boombox. ("Give us twenty-two minutes and we'll give you the world.") Sports, ads, bullshit -- LETOUR hears what he's been waiting for:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Actions have consequences.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (out of shot -- radio) This story is just in. A woman has fallen thirty stories to her death from a posh Grace Towers apartment on Lexington Avenue. Police are withholding identification pending the notification of the next of kin. The incident happened about ten p.m. According to the sources on the scene there was no one else in the posh Grace Towers apartment when the fall occurred. We will bring you more details as we get them. (teletype efx) An end to the sanitation strike seems imminent. Negotiations at the Helmsley Palace are continuing to this hour...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: First light. Jones Street. LETOUR, sleepless, pounds on Teresa's door. No answer. Knocks again. Again. Noises from inside. A sleepy voice:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: John. John LeTour. Can I see you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (out of shot) What time is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (out of shot) Call. Make an appointment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Open the door. You're awake anyway. (no answer) Teresa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: wearing oriental bathrobe, unlatches the door. JOHN enters, turns to her. The door closes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Read me. What do you see?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We had a session last week. What do you see?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: takes a moment to concentrate.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Step back. (he does) Again. (he does) Death.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This was not an accident. This person was murdered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat) There is danger around you. It's very close. I'm sleepy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. Don't be afraid. Go home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: shuffles toward her bedroom -- the "reading" is over.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing. Forget it. Let me sleep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mid-morning. LETOUR, still awake, walks past towering Chelsea trash. He passes a newsstand. Tabloids feature yearbook photo of MARIANNE; the headline: "Fall from Grace."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: walks to a pay phone, takes out Guidone's card, inserts a quarter, dials.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: suspicious, looks around. GUIDONE speaks:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hangs up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is John LeTour. Remember me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (out of shot) Laundromat. Your father's got connections.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You said I should ask around, tell you something you didn't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (out of shot) I thought you'd call.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It ain't much, but it's something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A girl died last night. Lexington Ave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The news said she was alone in the apartment when she went out -- she wasn't. It's a cover-up. There was someone else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's all I know. You asked me to tell you something. I told you something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Noon. LETOUR enters a West Village apartment building. He presses an intercom button. Robert's voice answers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door buzzes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: opens the door to his overdecorated apartment. JOHN looks around. TONY, Robert's younger, unattractive lover, sips coffee at the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Words blur to jargon. LETOUR cuts in:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Turns to bathroom.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where have you been? We were worried.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I need some sleep -- not much. I don't want to go home just yet. A little sleep first. Can I crash here? Nice place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's hideous. I did it years ago. I've got to throw everything out. You haven't been here? (noticing TONY) Oh, Jack, this is Tony. I told you about him. You should talk. He's the lapidopterist -- gems.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you know about Tis? What's his relationship to Ann?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They go way back -- before me. Did you cross him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't. He's Ann's Ecstasy connection. She needs that score. What happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everybody's dangerous. We heard what you did to Eddie. Ann thought it was great. She was afraid that was why you didn't come back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was something else. Tell me if you hear anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tis who? Ann says you want a chart done. (beat) What's wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods) Yeah... (culling thoughts) You ever think about it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That it'd be like this -- like, your life, you... that it would turn out this way? -- ROBERT Compared to what? My thinking this or that is going to make any difference? There's a plan unfolding. "Will my plane crash?" "Does life have meaning?" -- why ask me? Thinking's a fear of living, negative living; living's something else. You're afraid. Let the plan unfold. Stop. Stop, live one day -- one day --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Robert -- ROBERT -- day at a time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (touches ROBERT) You've lost your fucking brain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a plastic bottle of bath oil in the cabinet. Yellow. Use it -- tell me what you think. It's a new formula.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Six p.m. LETOUR, shaved and bathed, rides a cab uptown, past Harlem, past 158th Street. He motions to the DRIVER; the taxi stops at a blue door between retail stores begging for renovation. TEENAGE LATINOS hang out. LETOUR gives the CABBIE a twenty. LETOUR walks to the blue door; the YOUTHS stop, watch. He knocks on the door. A PUERTO RICAN DOORMAN in white leather pants and a heart-shaped diamond ring opens the door, looks him over. JOHN reaches into his pouch, removes a gram envelope, hands it to him. The DOORMAN takes a taste, buzzes him through a door hand-lettered "Jump-Offs." Inside Jump-Offs, a cocaine "spot," every eye turns to JOHN: the only Anglo in a Hispanic after-hours club. Tough young faces, each with a style and two inches of attitude. Willie Colon plays on the jukebox. Searching, LETOUR recognizes a face, walks over:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Manny. (MANUEL, thirtyish, Puerto Rican, looks closer, trying to place LETOUR) LeTour. (helping out) Jealous. "Jell." SOB's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got a problem. I need a piece.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Piece? Piece of what? Piece of candy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now. Anything. (MANUEL is silent) Am I speaking too fast?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: calls over a TEENAGE DOMINICAN, explains the situation in Spanish. The DOMINICAN replies; MANUEL turns back to JOHN:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They lead him to an even darker back room. The DOMINICAN retrieves an automatic pistol from a trash pail, hands it to MANUEL. JOHN counts cash from Tis' roll; MANNY hefts the piece.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bills and guns exchanged.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The DOMINICAN laughs; LETOUR takes his measure.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He's got a 64 Smith-son. Detective Special. Nobody wants 'em. Fresh from a cop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't have much use for a gun. Never used one like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Simple. You put the bullets in -- (inserts cartridge) you point it at the bad guys, pull the trigger and they fall down!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: repeats this for the DOMINICAN ["bang, bang!"]; they laugh again. LETOUR eases the .38 into his crotch. MANNY turns, exchanges Latin hug:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: exits, works his way through the club.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John's apartment. Seven p.m. LETOUR, sweating, bareback, tucks the .38 under his futon. He takes a bottle of cologne from the bathroom, pours it over his hair, face, and torso, rubs it in. Licking his finger, he removes Marianne's gold and onyx ring with a tug. His finger stings. He opens a window, throws the ring full force into the junk-strewn courtyard. He shakes his torso; cologne glistens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Interior, Plaza Memorial Chapel. LETOUR enters the "viewing room," motions to RANDI. She follows him. They slip into a door, enter the embalming room: stainless steel table surrounded by surgical cabinets. They embrace, disengage. JOHN looks: Randi's exhausted face mirrors his.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Have you been to the police station?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods) She was back on drugs. Really back. They're gonna bring her here too. My God. (he comforts her) I thought she was playing for attention.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're not to blame. Don't blame yourself. You weren't responsible. She was always -- she loved you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wipes tear from her cheek) She loved you. You were what she wanted to be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: pulls a Polaroid from his pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The picture features ANN and TIS: side by side at a dinner party.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: His father's a lawyer. Did some tax things for Mom. He was at the hospital. What's that smell?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's me. Cologne. I'm a sucker for that cheap airplane stuff. Did Marianne mention him yesterday?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ("no") It was his apartment. What are you thinking?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She jumped. (LETOUR hangs on every word) You loved her, but she -- this sounds terrible but it's true -- she was... she ruined everything... bad luck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (heard enough) When's the funeral -- your mother's?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (vague) Well, I got this thing to do. It's -- I don't know if I can get away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ann's apartment. Eight p.m. ANN greets LETOUR with a hug.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry about last night. Something came up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (enters bedroom) I'm $500 short from last night. I'll get it, you can take it from my salary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stung) This is family. Are you saying that to hurt me? (LETOUR returns) It's not money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look at this. ("Akasha" visual) We had a graphic artist make it up -- you know, Billy, Five Towns.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The label for the cosmetics line.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tis called twice. He wants you to come by.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Says you were supposed to show up again yesterday, but didn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A lie. I don't want to go. The suicide and all. Let's stay away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't. He's the Ecstasy connect. No way I can fuck this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: suspicious, looks from ANN to ROBERT. He knows TIS knows he knows MARIANNE was not alone when she went out the window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Just is -- so he's a bigot? What's new? So's everybody else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want to go. I got a bad vibe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to ANN) Why don't you go? He's your contact.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He is -- ANN (to ROBERT) You giving orders?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (testing her) Come with me -- the two of us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (upbeat) Okay. You got it. Like old times -- Ann and Johnny. (turns to go)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop it. You're breaking my heart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Night. ANN and LETOUR side by side in the sedan. CARLOS, at the wheel, anonymous. Outside, SANITATION WORKERS toss sacks of trash into garbage trucks: the strike is over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: reminisces as lights flash:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's going to be strange, not doing this. I mean I've had it, but sometimes...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're gonna do it, aren't you? You're gonna quit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods) I think so. Seal this thing with Tis, turn it -- go with the cosmetics. You gotta take a chance in life. No risk, no gain. I've already got retail connections here, London. It was great at the beginning, though.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, when we first started out of the place on Greene Street. Before deliveries, when you were still using. It was open house every night but Sunday. We had everything: uppers, downers, meth, six kinds of hash, all in that trousseau, remember? You could get in for a gram, stay all night -- everybody, music people, movies, Wall Street, fashion -- even politics. I think like five marriages came out of those parties, babies -- really. God. (JOHN eyes her: why this Niagara, this nostalgia?) You stayed, you then Robert -- but he... I'da never thought you'd, what is it, twelve years? Others, lucky a year max, eight months, in, out, start using, unreliable -- nice kids. Remember when you first came: long hair, dirty fingers -- LETOUR (overlapping) You made me -- ANN -- never washed -- LETOUR -- khaki pants.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I should write a book someday. Did you know somebody wanted to do my story? Ghostwrite. It was impossible, of course -- my lawyer freaked I even had the meeting. People envy me. They think my life is so glamorous, but they don't know. I know. Glamorous. (beat) It was for a while. Then came crack and fucked everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: wonders: The Big Goodbye? Is she acting at Tis' behest?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "They're?"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sedan continues south. It turns, stops in front of John's Chelsea apartment building.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I gotta stop home a second.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why? It's out of the way. They're expecting you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know I got a bad vibe about Tis.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to get my lucky jacket.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: hops out, goes in. Inside John's apartment he -- a man possessed -- pulls his black tweed from the closet, throws it on the futon. He rolls up his shirt, reaches under the futon, removes the .38. He straps the gun to his back, wraps duct tape around his chest, end to end over the .38. He tucks in his shirt, puts on the jacket, checks the mirror to see if the gun shows: it doesn't. A pause to appreciate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: closes his diary, throws it out the window: a trifle. He slaps cologne on his cheeks -- annointing; heads toward the door. Outside, LETOUR emerges, walks quickly to the car, plops beside ANN. The sedan drives off. Back seat:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That took long enough. What did you do, douche while you were at it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ann, you got some mouth on you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't want to know where it's been. (sniffs him) Cologne?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Phew. It smells like that stuff they give you on airplanes. It's no good for your skin. All chemicals.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: pulls out a slip of paper, writes a name and address: "Linda Wichel, 1012B-2 A Street, Sacramento, California."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Extends slip of paper.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (testing again) If anything happens to me -- if I should like, you know, fucking die -- write and tell her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: starts to speak, stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes the name and address.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's my sister. Her husband's in San Quentin. She worries, you know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: sad, looks out the window. She touches his knee. The car pulls in front of the Pennsylvania Hotel, 34th and 7th.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They get out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I thought we were going to Tis'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We are. He's here. He can't very well work out of his apartment after what happened yesterday, can he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Pennsylvania lobby: a baseball card convention is in progress. ANN squeezes through, goes to the house phone. JOHN follows, scans the tacky lobby: what's up?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They go to the elevators, wait with CHATTY CARD COLLECTORS [Pete Rose this, Pete Rose that]. Twelfth floor. ANN and JOHN step out of the elevator, look for 1204.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (on phone) Mathis Bruge, please. (beat) Tis? Ann. I'm here with Tour. (beat) Okay. (hangs up)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: a step behind, is all eyes, all ears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: checks the number, rings the bell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: lets them in the standard issue suite, locks the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: was right: it's a set-up. THOMAS and a TEENAGE CUBAN stand either side of them, waistbands conspicuously bulging. No TIS. JOHN turns to ANN:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ANN's confused, then furious: she had no part in the "set- up." In fact, she doesn't even know it's a set-up. Bursting rage, she turns on THOMAS, YELLS:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She slaps THOMAS, pulls the 9mm from his waistband, throws it to the carpet. The CUBAN watches bewildered, gun drawn, awaiting instructions. Now ANN's on him:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I told you greasy fucks I don't deal with guns! I see guns, I walk! How dare you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you, beaner, whoever the fuck you are, kiss my fat ass! (she spits on his shirt, knees him in the crotch, yanks his gun, throws it beside the gut- clutching CUBAN. She crosses the room, YELLING:) That's it! TIS! Shitball! I know you're fucking there! Let this be a lesson! You wanna deal, you gonna apologize for this! (to LETOUR) Let's go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: and the CUBAN TEEN retrieve their guns; ANN unlocks the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns defiantly. TIS enters from bedroom:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (pointing gun) Hold it! Stop right there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to THOMAS) No! (to ANN) Sorry about the guns. My fuck-up. I was just trying to make a point -- I apologize.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: looks to THOMAS and the CUBAN: they lower their weapons. He only means to threaten LETOUR.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ANN gets it. Fear hits:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Opens door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (about THOMAS and CUBAN) Assholes. What a nightmare. (to ANN) We'll make the deal tomorrow -- same terms. Ann. Sorry. Go on, leave, you're upset. I just need to talk to Tour a second. About a police matter. (to LETOUR) Right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tour and I need to get our stories straight. Somebody's talking to the police. The guns were for emphasis, to make a point, dumb --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to TIS) We came together, we're leaving together. (to LETOUR) Johnny, come with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: fixes his gun on ANN.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to ANN) Don't be stupid. Get out. Leave. (to LETOUR) I had nothing to do with Marianne -- she jumped: she was there, then she was gone. (nods ANN to leave) Nothing will happen to Tour.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: computes, bolts out, flees, SCREAMING at the top of her lungs:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The fire bell rings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and the CUBAN stare dumbfounded.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: reaches behind his shirt in the confusion, yanks out the .38 with a painful rip, turning, fires point-blank into the Cuban's chest. BLAM! Shirt fabric flares, flies: the CUBAN falls with blank expression.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: off guard, wheels and fires wildly at LETOUR.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: fires back. Both are hit. TIS ducks into the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and LETOUR fire again, again -- hitting, missing. A bullet hits its mark: THOMAS, frozen, grabs his blood-spurting throat, slumps to floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: bleeds from the stomach and shoulder. His shirt soaks red; he struggles to stand. CUBAN and THOMAS -- both dead. LETOUR checks the .38: five rounds fired -- one left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: staggers into the bedroom, finds TIS frantically searching an open suitcase. Off-screen VOICES under the fire bell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LETOUR steps to TIS, aims, shoots him barrel to forehead. Exit debris hits the wall. He is dead. Off-screen screams of guests are countered by commands from hotel security: "Get down!" "Get back!" Fire horns and sirens reverb from the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: losing consciousness, sits bedside. Gun slips from his hand. Deflating, he drifts back-first to the bedspread. Blood spreads. His eyes are open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: approach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prison waiting area. ANN, wearing a wool suit, waits among black/Hispanic FRIENDS and RELATIVES. The first scene without LETOUR: she sits quietly. A CORRECTIONS OFFICER instructs the visitors to proceed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: walks through a concrete corridor, finds the visiting area.
direction.name: direction
